facts.text: Sadhu Ram killed on 5th November 1953 at about 6:45 PM at shop of Vas Dev PW 2

anchor.surface_text: On the facts alleged by the prosecution there can be numberdoubt that Sadhu Ram was killed on the 5th of November, 1953,

facts.text: Appellant along with others assaulted Sadhu Ram

anchor.surface_text: at about 6-45 P.m. at the shop of Vas Dev P. W. 2. It is alleged that the appellant along with others assaulted Sadhu Ram.

facts.text: Appellant armed with a takwa during assault

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was armed with a takwa. Numerous injuries were found on the person of Sadhu Ram.

facts.text: Prosecution denied deceased assaulted by any other person with takwa

anchor.surface_text: It was denied by the prosecution that the deceased was assaulted by any other person with a takwa.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge held charge of rioting not proved

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Sessions Judge, however, held, that the charge of rioting was number proved.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted appellant and three others under s302/34 IPC

anchor.surface_text: He, accordingly found the appellant and three others guilty under section 302 read with section 34 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted the other three accused

anchor.surface_text: but altered the companyviction of the other accused from section 302/34 to section 323, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: High Court held provisions of section 34 IPC did not apply

anchor.surface_text: it held that the provisions of section 34 of the Indian Penal Code did number apply.

arguments.claim: Appellant misled by charge under 302/149 indicating not charged with individual murder

anchor.surface_text: By framing a charge under section 302, read with section 149 of the Indian Penal Code against the appellant, the Court indicated that it was not charging the appellant with the offence of murder

holdings.text: A person charged with an offence read with section 149 IPC cannot be convicted of the substantive offence under section 302 IPC without a specific charge being framed under section 233 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: After an examination of the cases referred to on behalf of the appellant and the prosecution we are of the opinion that the view taken by the Calcutta High Court is the correct view namely, that a person charged with an offence read with section 149 cannot be convicted of the substantive offence without a specific charge being framed as required by section 233 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s149 creates distinct specific offence from substantive murder; requires separate charge per CrPC s233; follows Calcutta HC precedents over Madras; Privy Council observations supportive; rejects respondent's view equating to s34.

holdings.text: Section 149 IPC creates a specific offence distinct from section 34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary, therefore, to examine the provisions of section 149 of the Indian Penal Code and consider as to whether this section creates a specific offence. Section 149 of the Indian Penal Code is to be found in Chapter VIII of that Code which deals with offences against the public tranquillity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s149 in Ch VIII imposes constructive liability on unlawful assembly members without intention; unlike explanatory s34 requiring common intention; punishment from underlying offence; s40 IPC does not preclude as no uniform punishment needed.

holdings.text: Provisions of sections 236 and 237 CrPC do not apply as there is no doubt about the facts or which offence was committed.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged by the Prosecution that under the provisions of section 236 and section 237 of the Code of Criminal Procedure a person could be convicted of an offence which he is shown to have committed although he was not charged with it. Section 237... In the present case there is no doubt about the facts and if the allegations against the appellant that he had caused the injuries...

holdings.reasoning_summary: s236 applies only where doubt on offence from proved facts; here facts clearly establish appellant committed murder directly with takwa.

holdings.text: Absence of charge under s302 IPC is an illegality not curable under sections 535 and 537 CrPC, and occasioned failure of justice.

anchor.surface_text: It had been argued on behalf of the prosecution that no finding or sentence pronounced shall be deemed invalid merely on the ground that no charge was framed... In the present case, however, there is no question of any error, omission or irregularity in the charge because no charge under section 302 of the Indian Penal Code was in fact framed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No charge framed at all = illegality, not irregularity; prejudice shown; ss535/537 cure only errors/omissions, not total absence for distinct offence.

holdings.text: Appellant was misled in his defence by absence of charge under s302 IPC, occasioning failure of justice warranting setting aside conviction.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case we are of the opinion that there was an illegality and not an irregularity curable by the provisions of sections 535 and 537... we are satisfied that... the appellant was misled in his defence by the absence of a charge under section 302 of the Indian Penal Code. By framing a charge under section 302, read with section 149...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge under 302/149 signalled no individual murder charge; appellant did not fully contest medical evidence on injuries or witness testimony on takwa use; would have cross-examined differently if charged directly.

holdings.text: High Court correctly held that section 34 IPC did not apply to the facts.

anchor.surface_text: it held that the provisions of section 34 of the Indian Penal Code did not apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts High Court finding; s34 requires common intention, inapplicable where s149/302 charge failed and facts showed individual act.

holdings.text: Conviction under 302/149 cannot be converted to 302 alone when s34 also inapplicable, as no charge under substantive 302.

anchor.surface_text: There could be no valid objection, therefore, to converting a conviction under section 302/34 into one under section 302 which the High Court did. This argument is unacceptable. The High Court clearly found that section 34 was not applicable to the facts of the case...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Karnail Singh (allowed 302/149 to 302/34); here trial court wrongly used 302/34, High Court rejected s34, cannot leap to uncharged 302.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case we are of the opinion that there was an illegality and number an irregularity curable by the provisions of sections 535 and 537 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Assuming, however, for a moment that there was merely an irregularity which was curable we are satisfied that, in the circumstances of the present case, the irregularity is number curable because the appellant was misled in his defence by the absence of a charge under section 302 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: After an examination of the cases referred to on behalf of the appellant and the prosecution we are of the opinion that the view taken by the Calcutta High Court is the correct view namely, that a person charged with an offence read with section 149 cannot be convicted of the substantive offence without a specific charge being framed as required by section 233 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

In the present case we are of the opinion that there was an illegality and number an irregularity curable by the provisions of sections 535 and 537 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Assuming, however, for a moment that there was merely an irregularity which was curable we are satisfied that, in the circumstances of the present case, the irregularity is number curable because the appellant was misled in his defence by the absence of a charge under section 302 of the Indian Penal Code.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 states Section 149 IPC creates a specific offence distinct from section 34 IPC, directly addressing issue i2 on whether section 149 creates a specific offence

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary, therefore, to examine the provisions of section 149 of the Indian Penal Code and consider as to whether this section creates a specific offence. Section 149 of the Indian Penal Code is to be found in Chapter VIII of that Code which deals with offences against the public tranquillity.

In the present case we are of the opinion that there was an illegality and number an irregularity curable by the provisions of sections 535 and 537 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Assuming, however, for a moment that there was merely an irregularity which was curable we are satisfied that, in the circumstances of the present case, the irregularity is number curable because the appellant was misled in his defence by the absence of a charge under section 302 of the Indian Penal Code.

Assuming, however, for a moment that there was merely an irregularity which was curable we are satisfied that, in the circumstances of the present case, the irregularity is number curable because the appellant was misled in his defence by the absence of a charge under section 302 of the Indian Penal Code.
